ANG MO KIO CONSTITUENCY
(Expansion of medical services)


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Health, in view of the increasing population in the Housing and Development Board and surrounding estates in Ang Mo Kio, (a) if he will consider expanding the facilities provided in the Toa Payoh Hospital and Bright Hill Drive Clinic; and (b) when a polyclinic will be built in Ang Mo Kio Estate and what are the facilities that will be provided.

     The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not possible to expand facilities in Bright Hill Drive Clinic because of physical constraints. Construction of Ang Mo Kio Polyclinic will begin in the middle of 1979 and will be completed in early 1981. The Polyclinic will provide outpatient, curative, maternal, child health, family planning, dental and psychiatric services. There will also be facilities for X-ray and minor surgery.

    As for Toa Payoh Hospital, I share with the Member for Ang Mo Kio the same concern. Toa Payoh Hospital was built in 1957, before the PAP came to power. In the first instance, it was built in the wrong place, on top of a hill and is inaccessible to patients. In the second place, at that time Toa Payoh housing estate and Ang Mo Kio housing estate were never conceived at all. So today we find that Toa Payoh Hospital which has less than 800 beds has got to serve two enormous housing estates plus the population from Sembawang.

    I have visited Toa Payoh Hospital on a number of occasions and have suggested how we could improve or increase the facilities at Toa Payoh Hospital. But the terrain is such that we have to embark upon a major development scheme, if at all Toa Payoh Hospital is going to improve its facilities. As of this moment, I regret to say

Column: 838

that we can do very little except to move the student nurses who are living there out of their quarters or to move the housemen who stay there and convert some of the buildings into wards. That can be done at short notice, But it is an unsatisfactory solution. However, we are trying to manage and initial steps have been taken to convert some of these quarters into wards.

    However, may I also add that those who are living in the Ang Mo Kio area or Toa Payoh area need not necessarily go to Toa Payoh Hospital if it is overcrowded. They can have access to Tan Tock Seng Hospital which is close by. This, of course, touches on the point which the Member for Kim Seng raised in the debate on the estimates for my Ministry, that is, the problem of rezoning of patient catchment areas for the different hospitals.

    As I pointed out, a hospital is a long-lived building. But Singapore is in a state of flux. A criticism has been made at my Ministry by a consultant - and I think it is a well made criticism - that all these donkey's years the Ministry has never had a long-term policy. This is a point which has been driven home to my administrators, and we are trying as best as we can to correct the errors of omission.

    Nonetheless, Sir, Members in the House will realise that health care is very personal. In many countries, it is no longer pushed into the back of the budget of a government. Health care can be inflationary in character and, in fact, in the United States it is. It is a great contributor to the cost of living. Likewise, in other European countries health has become a political issue. We have done our best up to date. But I am afraid that policies of other Ministries sometimes overtake policies in the Ministry of Health. I have now made it a point that my administrators in the Ministry catch up with other Ministries which are responsible for urban renewal or resettlement of population, so that we will not be left high and dry.

CPF CONTRIBUTIONS BY HAWKERS


    3. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Labour whether it is feasible for

Column: 839

the Central Provident Fund Board to work together with the Hawkers Department of the Ministry of the Environment to request all licensed hawkers to contribute to the Central Provident Fund as compulsory savings for future purchase of Housing and Development Board flats and for old age.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the desirability and feasibility of requiring hawkers to contribute to CPF should first be examined before we decide to bring them within the CPF scheme.

    Those in favour of requiring hawkers to contribute would argue that hawkers require financial protection when they grow too old to provide for themselves. While some of them earn good incomes, many are only making a marginal living with hardly anything to set aside for old age. Those able to save could have their savings wiped out by business failures or other misfortunes. Hence, bringing them within the CPF scheme would enable them to save for old age.

    On the other hand, those against the idea would argue that hawkers earning a meagre income would hardly have enough to contribute to the CPF. To require them to do so would only add to their hardship.

    Furthermore, a hawker's income fluctuates from month to month. There is, therefore, difficulty in determining the monthly income of hawkers to decide the amount that they should contribute. The inflationary impact of requiring hawkers to contribute should not be discounted. There is also the problem of the collection of CPF contributions from hawkers, especially if the monthly contribution is small.

    The CPF Board is now studying the desirability and feasibility of requiring hawkers to contribute to CPF.

ACCIDENTS INVOLVING MINISTRY
OF THE ENVIRONMENT VEHICLES
(Particulars)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for the Environment how many vehicles of his Ministry were involved in accidents in 1976, 1977 and 1978: how many of the accidents were serious and how many resulted in fatalities; and what steps have been or are being taken to reduce the number of accidents to the minimum.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member for Punggol may be glad to hear that the rate of accident in which vehicles of the Ministry of the Environment were involved has fallen during the years.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Very good!

     Mr Lim Kim San: In 1976, the Ministry of the Environment had 567 vehicles. These were involved in 356 accidents of which three were serious and two were fatal. In 1977, there were 585 vehicles in the Ministry. There were 317 accidents of which four were serious and one was fatal. In 1978, the Ministry of the Environment had 608 vehicles and there were 268 accidents. Of these, three were serious and none was fatal.

    Sir, what-steps are taken to further reduce the rate of accidents? In the Ministry of the Environment, each driver is given a simple handbook on safe driving. In addition, the drivers are briefed from time to time on safe driving. Drivers of specialised vehicles like refuse collection vehicles and mechanical sweepers are given special training before they are allowed to drive. In addition to police action, departmental disciplinary action is also taken from time to time to see that drivers drive safely.

    To further minimise accidents, all the vehicles are regularly maintained. Each vehicle is inspected and serviced at least once in 40 days.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask the Minister whether all these 268 accidents for last year have

Column: 841

occurred as a result of the faults of the Ministry of the Environment's drivers?

     Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, offhand, I would say that it cannot be because the law of averages does not allow it. It is impossible that all the 268 accidents were due to the fault of the drivers of the Ministry of the Environment. The drivers of the Ministry were responsible for some but not all the accidents.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, while I thank the Hon. Minister for his kind reply and for the figures on the number of accidents, I would like to refer him to the observation that in 1976 and 1977, over 60% of the vehicles were involved in accidents and in 1978 the accident rate dropped to over 40%. My question is: besides giving a handbook to the drivers and regularly maintaining the vehicles, are the drivers given incentives for accident-free driving for periods from six months up to a year? If incentives are given, does the Minister agree that the accident rate could be further reduced, to less than 40%?

     Mr Lim Kim San: That is the ultimate objective, Sir, but as the saying goes, "A journey of a thousand miles starts with the first step."

RESITING OF HAWKERS IN
HAWKER/FOOD CENTRES


    5. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for the Environment how many more licensed hawkers are to be resited in hawker/food centres and the period it will take to complete this process; what are the hawker/food centres to be built in FY 1979/80; and whether his Ministry has a set of guidelines in the planning of the size or number of hawker/food centres in Housing and Development Board estates in the matter of the ratio of population to hawkers in the estates.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for the Environment)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 6,695 licensed street hawkers, including 465 itinerant and 86 showcase

Column: 842

hawkers. About 5,000 of them will be resited by 1981 and the rest will be later in stages.

    Thirteen markets and/or food centres will be completed in FY 1979/80. Four will be located in Ang Mo Kio, three in Bedok, two in Clementi and one each in Lim Chu Kang, Bukit Merah, Woodlands and Bukit Batok, Twelve other centres are planned - one each in Clementi, Kreta Ayer, Kandang Kerbau, Bedok, Nee Soon New Town, Woodlands New Town, Tampines New Town, Bukit Batok New Town, Kampong Java, Hill Street, Telok Ayer and Farrer Park.

    There are guidelines in planning markets and/or food centres in HDB estates. There will be one market-produce stall to 50 units of flats, or about 250 persons. Similarly, there will be one cooked-food stall to 100 units of flats or about 500 persons.

SECRET SOCIETIES
(Areas of activity)


    6. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) how many secret societies are still active in Singapore and in which areas they are most active; and (b) whether he has received any report or information about their infiltration into youth groups or organisations.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 37 active secret societies comprising 110 gangs operating in various parts of Singapore. They are more active in certain areas in Jalan Besar and Geylang, and in rural areas such as Jurong and Sembawang. Some are found in Housing Board estates. The Police are keeping these areas under close surveillance.

    There is no evidence of secret society elements infiltrating youth groups or organisations.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, since there are still so many secret societies and so many gangs in so many constituencies, even in Housing Board estates, what steps does the Hon. Minister for Home Affairs propose to take to eliminate them?

Column: 843



     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, as I have said, the Police are maintaining very close surveillance on areas where they are still active. When there are cases of secret society incidents, they are investigated and we make use of the powers of detention under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act. But over the years we have less and less incidents of secret society activity in Singapore.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, in this respect would the Hon. Minister for Home Affairs enlighten this House as to the type and structure of these secret societies or gangs, and whether their modus operandi is the same as the secret society of yesterday?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, they are still the triad type of secret societies. They have their initiation ceremonies and so on. Their common types of activity are extortion, crimes, and so on. They still have their traditional methods of operation. At the same time they also have modernised. Of course, they also take into consideration the lie of the land when they commit these activities. We also counter these new techniques and methods.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Sir, can I ask the Minister if he will enlighten this House on the reasons why gangsterism is so predominant in the areas he highlighted?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I feel that the Member for Kim Seng is asking me a rhetorical question. I think he knows why they are still active in certain areas like Jalan Besar and Geylang. The straight answer is that in Jalan Besar and Geylang there are still some red light areas.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon: Sir, can I ask the Minister another question? Is it because there is a need to preserve these red light areas that he is not able to flush out all the gangsters?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, that again is another rhetorical question. The answer is that there is no such need to preserve such areas.

ACCIDENTS INVOLVING MINISTRY OF DEFENCE VEHICLES
(Particulars)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister of Defence how many vehicles of his Ministry were involved in accidents in 1976, 1977 and 1978; how many of the accidents were serious and how many were fatal; and what steps have been or are being taken to reduce the number of accidents to the minimum.

     The Minister of Defence (Mr Howe Yoon Chong): Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to the question from the Member for Punggol, the figures he has requested are as follows.

    In 1976 SAF vehicles involved in traffic accidents totalled 1,457. Of these accidents, three resulted in fatalities and 175 involved serious injuries. The corresponding figures for 1977 were 1,271 with eight fatalities and 190 involving serious injuries. For 1978 there were 1,351 accidents with four fatalities and 232 involving serious injuries. I think all of us are concerned that these figures should be reduced as far as possible.

    The Ministry of Defence is taking various measures to curb the SAF accident rate. These measures include:

    (a) strict enforcement of speed limits on military vehicles by military police motorcycle squads;

    (b) imposition of fines on drivers and vehicle commanders found guilty of speeding and negligence;

    (c) special instructions on defensive driving to teach SAF drivers how to handle road hazards, such as skidding;

    (d) restriction of movement of heavy military vehicles like low-loaders, to only off-peak hours under military police escort;

    (e) proper vehicle maintenance, with strict inspection at regular intervals to ensure road worthiness of every MINDEF vehicle.

    In addition to the above, certain preventive measures are also taken. These include:

    (a) incentives for accident-free regular driver;

Column: 845



    (b) qualification for civilian driving licence on completion of two years' driving provided that there has been no blemish of more than two traffic accidents;

    (c) withdrawal of accident prone drivers for proficiency tests and transfer of those who cannot pass such tests;

    (d) transfer of drivers away from driving immediately after an accident involving death until after the Traffic Police or the Civil Courts have exonerated them.

    By the middle of this year it is hoped that a special driving circuit will be ready at Keat Hong to improve the training facilities for SAF drivers. This driving circuit has been specially designed to enable trainee drivers to be exposed to all the possible road hazards and to prepare all SAF drivers adequately to drive safely and carefully on our public roads.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, does the Minister of Defence not disagree with me that most of the drivers of these vehicles are national servicemen? In that sense, they are very young, 18 years and above, and therefore considering this aspect would he not engage professional drivers with a view to further curbing the numerous accidents in the last three years?

     Mr Howe Yoon Chong: Sir, we in the Ministry of Defence consider driving as part of the instruction which national servicemen should have, because should we go to war we cannot say that we should have professional drivers to drive our lorries. I agree with him that the drivers are all very young because they come in only for a stint of two to 2 1/2 years of national service. This is something we cannot avoid. If we want soldiers, we want soldiers who are not only able to fight but also soldiers who are able to get others to the front to fight. Therefore, it is necessary that we continue to employ only national service drivers.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: If that is the case, Sir, maybe the hon. Minister thinks that the measures, both preventive and precautionary, are sufficient to help reduce the number of accidents involving vehicles of his Ministry. Therefore, my question is this:

Column: 846

would he not take more measures to further reduce the number of accidents given in the last three years?

    I wholeheartedly agree with the Minister that we should prepare our young soldiers to defend the country and that they also have got to know how to transport their fellow soldiers to the battle front.

     Mr Howe Yoon Chong: Sir, I do not think we can disagree with the Member for Punggol that even one accident is one accident too many. But I would like to submit for the information of the House that accident rates are dependent on a lot of other considerations besides drivers. Accidents depend on the number of vehicles on the road, the condition of the road, the condition of traffic, the condition of the drivers; and sometimes it may be due to the negligence of the other drivers as well. So we in the Ministry of Defence will try to train our drivers to be as proficient as possible but, as they say, accidents do happen.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, while I cannot wholeheartedly disagree with the Hon. Minister of Defence, I would also like to submit, with all the reasons given, whether the vehicles have been well maintained, as was pointed out by the Minister for the Environment just now in reply to my question concerning vehicles in his Ministry.

     Mr Howe Yoon Chong: Sir, I have stated just now that one of the measures that we take is regular maintenance and strict inspection of our vehicles. I can assure the Member for Punggol that Mindef vehicles are properly maintained and very strictly inspected at all times.

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Sir, as driving is part of the training, is he not a little alarmed at the standard of training that we have in the national service? In times of peace where conditions are not hostile, the accident rate is already high. What will happen then in times of war where conditions are more difficult? Would we be in a position to defend ourselves when our drivers are not able to drive without meeting accidents?

Column: 847



     Mr Howe Yoon Chong: Sir, may I submit that the hon. Member for Moulmein is probably prejudging the issue when he states that the accident rate involving Mindef vehicles is high. I do not want to make comparisons but I would like to give figures to show that our vehicles are no more prone to accidents than many other organisations that have the same number of vehicles. SAF has got 5,800 thin-skin vehicles, that is, not the armoured trucks but just the normal vehicles that we have on the roads, similar to commercial vehicles. Our accident rate is only 1,271 to 1,457 a year. If I am not mistaken, SBS has a smaller number of vehicles. It has got about 2,600 buses on the road, and I think their annual number of accidents is something like 4,800.

    The Minister for the Environment gave him some figures. They have got 608 vehicles and there were 268 accidents. If you compare it with our fleet of 5,800 vehicles, only about 1,300 to 1,400 were involved in accidents. I do not think it is right to make a statement that Mindef vehicles are more involved in accidents and that national servicemen cannot drive safely. As far as I know, it is quite creditable that our people have been able to train the national servicemen to drive as well as they do now.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, I cannot help making a little comment. I think the Backbench would only be too happy to offer a challenge trophy for an Inter-Ministry competition on road safety!

ARMY DRIVERS
(Training and tests)


    8. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister of Defence what is the duration of training and what tests are conducted for a National Serviceman before he is allowed to drive heavy vehicles on public roads.

     Mr Howe Yoon Chong: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is a continuation of the debate. As far as the SAF is concerned, we have a seven-week Basic Drivers Course. This means that we put our national servicemen through a seven-week driving instruction period. During this

Column: 848

course, each driver is given a minimum of 60 hours' practical driving on a three-ton truck. At the end of the course, the trainee driver is given a test conducted along the same lines as that for the ROV Class IV (heavy vehicles/lorries) driving licence. The test includes knowledge of highway code, practical road driving, parallel parking, reversing and three-point turn, After passing the driving test, the trainee driver is given a further week of experience driving a Land Rover before he is posted to a unit as a qualified driver for motor vehicles.

    In the unit he is given a further one-month continuation training course before he is allowed to drive three-ton trucks to carry SAF personnel from one point to another.

(Raising of income ceiling)


    9. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the rise in total family incomes in recent years, if the Housing and Development Board will consider raising the income ceilings for all types of flats.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think in the next month or two.

CYCLE TRACKS


    10. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the increasing number of cyclists killed or injured in road accidents, if he will consider providing separate lanes for cyclists along new roads, especially in industrial estates.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, cycle tracks have been provided along major

Column: 849

roads, such as, Queensway, Alexandra Road, Lorong Chuan, Adam Road, Lornie Road and Nicoll Highway. Industrial areas which have been provided with cycle tracks are Commonwealth Avenue between North Buona Vista Road and Queen's Circus, and Corporation Road in Jurong Town. However, these cycle tracks are poorly used by cyclists. The provision of cycle tracks along major roads has, therefore, been discontinued.

    Provision of cycle tracks will not reduce road accidents unless cyclists use the cycle tracks and observe the traffic rules. We will consider providing cycle tracks in new housing/industrial estates in future if a clear need exists.

TRAVEL AGENTS
(Particulars)


    11. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) how many travel agents have been registered; (b) how many of them have violated the law; (c) how many complaints have been received by the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board from the travelling public that they have been cheated by travel agents; and (d) in the light of the operation of the Travel Agents Act, whether the present law is adequate to protect the welfare of the travelling public.

     The Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Trade and Industry who has had to leave for Jakarta today has asked me to reply to this Question.

    The Singapore Tourist Promotion Board has licensed 307 travel agencies under the Travel Agents Act and its supplementary Regulations of 1976.

    Eight companies and one individual have violated the law. Eight of the offenders were prosecuted for operating as unlicensed travel agents. The remaining one offender, a licensed travel agent, was prosecuted for sharing commission with an unlicensed travel agent.

    The Singapore Tourist Promotion Board has received 87 complaints of cheating by

Column: 850

travel agents. Most of the complaints have been settled amicably between the parties concerned. There are only four outstanding complaints. Inquiries on these are being pursued by the Board of the cases settled, where the complaints of cheating were found to be justified, the travel agents concerned, on the advice of the Board, have paid compensation to the complainants. Where complaints of poor services have been proved, the travel agents concerned have been warned to improve their services. The Board has, therefore, been able to influence and control the travel agencies effectively.

    The present law is adequate to protect the welfare of the travelling public. The Travel Agents Act requires travel agencies to have a minimum paid-up capital of $50,000, to provide to the STPB a bank guarantee of $10,000 and to make a non-refundable cash contribution of $1,000 to the Compensation Fund to be used to compensate persons suffering hardship or loss as a result of actions of travel agents. In addition, heavy penalties are provided in the Act to deter malpractices. The remedies under the Act have been publicised and are now well-known to the public. The Board will continue to be alert at all times to possible malpractices by travel agents.

    Head N -

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (Mountbatten): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of Object Group 1210 of Subhead Code NA-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, fortunately for us, there are only a very small number of people in the civil service whom I feel do not apply enough commonsense in the implementation of

Column: 851

regulations and/or Government policies. Though this number is small, Sir, I believe it can lead to frustration of the people. It can also lead to frustration of work. In my opinion, there are two reasons why this could happen. Firstly, I feel that Government officers are not giving enough recognition to junior officers for their work. Secondly, I feel that junior officers themselves may be frustrated when they go about their work because they may be made scapegoats to problems that may arise in the implementation of regulations or any decisions.
